node.title: Singular Matrix Error in Flow past a cylinder problem
node.bodyText:
Hello,
  I'm setting up a similar simulation to #17470 except that I am doing a 2D problem for now.
  The geometry is set up as:


  Also, uniform refinement will be applied in MOOSE input for convergence purpose. All my input files used are attached in the zip file.

  First, I started with a FEM approach (Flow_Past_a_Cylinder_FE_ins.i) which the results looks reasonable.

 Since my alternate goal is to model compressible flow, I then tried to run simulations with FVM approach for both incomprehensible and compressible flow.

 I used the Mr. Lindsay's (@lindsayad) branch for the compressible flow, the simulation proceed for few timestep but then ran into bad convergence. He did mention the transient feature is not fully supported yet but I'm not sure if the problem is more related to my problem setup.

 Then I used Mr. Giudicelli (@GiudGiud) branch for the incompressible flow simulation. I would like to do transient problem but I got this "Matrix A is singular!" error even for the steady state case:


 The input file is adapted from modules\navier_stokes\test\tests\finite_volume\pins\channel-flow\heated\2d-rc-heated-boussinesq.i

 I wonder what could be wrong with my setup?

Flow_Past_a_Cylinder.zip
Thank you!
Zeyu Chen

Hi Zeyu
I took a look at the inputs (the incompressible fv one) you had posted on the previous thread and I had a few comments:

you should use rc interpolation for velocity instead of average.This will remove oscillations in pressure and improve convergence
you should use the Newton solve type since INSFV uses automatic differentiation
you should remove the forcing function kernels. These are used for MMS testing, not for real simulations
After that your simulation converged on my laptop

Best,
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
 I assume you are referring to the "Flow_Past_a_Cylinder_Fv_ins.i"

 I tried to modify the input file with your suggestions, after that,

 at first it says: 
    A 'NSFVMassFluxAdvection' is not a registered object.
    -- I guess this is because I switched to your branch, and I have to change it back to INSFVMassFluxAdvection
        (btw I can't pull #17538 anymore, do you have any idea why?)

 Now, the Singular Matrix Error is solved, but I'm still getting bad convergence even at the first timestep.

--- Zeyu Chen

---update:
I used
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_asm_overlap -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_levels'
petsc_options_value = 'asm      2               ilu          4'
and now it seemed to converge for the first several "real time" seconds, then failed afterwards.
By looking at the output, the simulation looks actually pretty good before reaching a "steady state".
Do you have any idea why this is happening? I suspect it is related to the temperature.
Flow_Past_a_Cylinder_fv_ins.zip
Thank you,
Zeyu Chen

It worked fine for the whole transient with the previous petsc settings.
I was suspecting the pressure oscillations. The simulation seems converged to me, it just can't meet the convergence criterion for various reasons.
Either way maybe just relax your tolerance with
nl_abs_tol = 1e-10 nl_rel_tol = 1e-10
or automatic_scaling = true to your executioner block, see if that helps

Yes, you are right looks like to relaxed my tolerance that made it run for 70~80 time steps.
I relaxed my tolerance to nl_abs_tol = 1e-8 nl_rel_tol = 1e-8 and it converges now.
Thank you!
Zeyu Chen

node.title: How to combine a thermal and grain growth model using multiapp
node.bodyText:
Hi, I'm relatively new to MOOSE so forgive me if there is an obvious answer to this. I'm trying to combine the function_ellipsoid_heat_source model with a voronoi grain growth model. Both of these exist in the MOOSE library and I know they can be linked through use of multiapp, likely with the thermal model being the master and the grain growth as a sub-app. I'm just not sure how to get them to pull from their respective libraries. Do I need to be registering them in the makefile? I didn't want to have to create a separate app, but would that be the best way?
Thank for the help in advance!

If you really don't want your own application. You can compile in the "modules" directory and get a "combined module" executable where you have access to all of the objects in all of the modules. You can then choose to setup a problem like this as a single monolith solve where everything is one nonlinear system (fully-coupled), or you could setup a Multiapp this way (both the master and sub would just be the combined module app) and do a loosely or tightly coupled solve between those two physics.
When you say a "combined module" executable do you mean like how if you compile in "combined" you get the combined-opt executable? Or is that the executable I should be using?

When running with the combined-opt it begins to run but then I get this error about an object not being registered which shouldn't they all be accessible in combined?
Running command: /home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined/combined-opt Outputs/csv=true -i peacock_run_exe_tmp_function_heat_source_master.i
Working directory: /home/aliyay/projects/moose/modules/combined
Creating MultiApp sub_app of type MooseTestApp of level 1 and number 0:
sub_app0:
*** ERROR ***
A 'PolycrystalVoronoi' is not a registered object.
If you are trying to find this object in a dynamically linked library, make sure that
the library can be found either in your "Problem/library_path" parameter or in the
MOOSE_LIBRARY_PATH environment variable.

If you don't want to build your own application, then yes, use the combined module to be able to use all moose objects currently existing
Indeed it should be registered, as PolyCrystalVoronoi is a phase field module object. Can you please attach the rest of the input file?
also does it run with the phase field module executable?
Guillaume

node.title: Converging but very slowly
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
My simulation converges quite nicely but takes a lot of time as timesteps increase. For instance, the transition from 17th to 18th time step took about 4 hours. I am not sure why since the first few timesteps only take a few minutes.
Here is my executioner block:
[Executioner]
type = Transient
solve_type = 'PJFNK'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_shift_type'
petsc_options_value = 'asm      ilu          nonzero'
l_max_its = 30
nl_max_its = 50
nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-10
automatic_scaling = true
end_time = 25
dt = 0.008
[./Adaptivity]
initial_adaptivity = 3
refine_fraction = 0.6
coarsen_fraction = 0.1
max_h_level = 3
[../]
[]
[Postprocessors]
[./dofs]
type = NumDOFs
[../]
[./integral]
type = ElementL2Error
variable = eta
function = ic_func_eta
[../]
[]
Is there anything that I can do to improve the speed of the calculations? I tried removing mesh adaptivity but the solution was really bad. The problem is a phase field-mechanics problem with an initial mesh of 40*40.
I am using a cluster system with 16 processors.
Thanks,
Bala

Hi Bala
Is the mesh refinement from adaptivity happening around the 17th time step? That could explain a slowdown. You can use the numdofs postprocessor to watch that.
I think the output log may be useful here to evaluate how the system is converging. Could you please attach it here
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your suggestion.
Mesh refinement is happening at every time step. I think I may have miswritten when I said 16th and 17th timestep. There are about 30 timesteps in between two timesteps when output is written. So it takes about 3 hours for 30 timesteps is what I meant.
I have attached the output file with the performance log.
Thanks,
Bala
el2b.txt

From your log it seems that a lot of time steps are failing because 10 non linear iterations (what I m seeing in the log, the block you pasted says 50) is not enough to reach the target residual. You should consider:

using a relative non linear tolerance criterion instead of an absolute
allowing more than 10 non linear iterations so the time steps fail less often

You could also increase the time step size if that is wise.
Have you tried the Newton solver? It might work better for your application.
In the log I see 28 processes. If your machine has 16 cores it's likely 16 processes will give the best performance.
I m not sure what happened with the log file. Let me try all these suggestions that you have given me and I will update on the status of the problem. Thank you for all the help.

Allowing more than 10 nonlinear iterations seem to help the convergence issue to a certain extent. The problem that I am running is a solidification problem. When two solid parts meet in the simulation the solution stops converging. I have referenced this problem in another related issue #16922 as well. I am attaching the output log file along with the debug file. It is kind of hard to figure out where the issue is. Any help would be greatly appreciated.
One of the performance output from the file is as below
Heaviest Sections:
|                  Section                 | Calls |   Self(s)  |    Avg.    |    %   |
| NonlinearSystemBase::computeJacobianTags |  5272 |    144.864 |      0.027 |  32.74 |
| FEProblem::solve                         |   210 |     82.631 |      0.393 |  18.67 |
| DisplacedProblem::updateMesh             | 11164 |     46.140 |      0.004 |  10.43 |
| FEProblem::checkExceptionAndStopSolve    | 72902 |     43.131 |      0.001 |   9.75 |
| NonlinearSystemBase::Kernels             |  5714 |     35.089 |      0.006 |   7.93 |
| AuxiliarySystem::computeElementalVars    |  5924 |     31.754 |      0.005 |   7.18 |
| FEProblem::meshChangedHelper             |   177 |     30.736 |      0.174 |   6.95 |
Thanks,
Bala
el2b_KHS_error.txt
el2b_KHS_output.txt
continued in #16922

node.title: Combination of domain solutions.
node.bodyText: Does Moose allow for the solution of equations (in time) in two separate domains? For example, T in Omega 1, and p in Omega 2, then another solution in a third domain Omega 3 using the solution of T, and p from the initial two solutions and then feedback into Omega 1 for another iteration of solutions?

Ah, so you would like to try and use the restart system to combine two solutions in some meanginful way.
Are the meshes different? or is it just two different problems solved on the same mesh?

Different mesh domains so that the mesh deformation in one domain has no effect on the other. The first domain (Energy Eq) has no internal geometry, the second domain has physical internal geometry (Structural Eq), the third domain only needs a mesh grid sufficient to capture the combined effects of the other two mesh domains. It then implicitly feeds information via a boundary equation back into the first to account for energy deformation based on the position of the second.

Thank you for your interest in my problem.

Get Outlook for iOS<https://aka.ms/o0ukef>
…
________________________________
From: John <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Sunday, February 28, 2021 1:42:23 PM

Cc: WISE, TAMMY <wisetl@email.sc.edu>; Author <author@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [idaholab/moose] Combination of domain solutions. (#17131)


Ah, so you would like to try and use the restart system to combine two solutions in some meanginful way.
Are the meshes different? or is it just two different problems solved on the same mesh?

Well if the first domain is just a scalar ODE you can use the ScalarKernels system to get your solution and then add them using a AuxKernel
I will solve the Naiver Stokes equation with density and viscosity properties that vary with pressure and temperature. Would the method you suggested be applicable for the NS equation in domain one?

I will solve the Naiver Stokes equation with density and viscosity properties that vary with pressure and temperature. Would the method you suggested be applicable for the NS equation in domain one?

Well if the first domain is just a scalar ODE you can use the ScalarKernels system to get your solution and then add them using a AuxKernel

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://protect2.fireeye.com/v1/url?k=b8eee29c-e775dbc7-b8eeac5d-862a37e2f896-b7919afe0108e3b1&q=1&e=0f050c55-4574-48a5-9221-cb0224fc4418&u=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fidaholab%2Fmoose%2Fdiscussions%2F17131%23discussioncomment-415666>, or unsubscribe<https://protect2.fireeye.com/v1/url?k=f5ca7ad3-aa514388-f5ca3412-862a37e2f896-5fcb047fbe6ecd42&q=1&e=0f050c55-4574-48a5-9221-cb0224fc4418&u=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fnotifications%2Funsubscribe-auth%2FAJQ6AYVHPBXZ5GFUVEKBGT3TBKHN7ANCNFSM4YFPGBMA>.

You may want to leverage the multiapp system to separate each solve.
Any specific reason you are trying to avoid coupling the equations in a single solve?

I am combining the equation of motion with heat transfer and fluid flow. When the systems of equations are coupled I experience deformation of the mesh and associated numerical error for large displacements of objects interior to the heat transfer/fluid domain. When I solve the equation of motion in it's own domain there are no mesh deformations or numerical errors.

So your options are:

a multiapp for each domain, and coupling through boundary conditions / transfers
separate domains are ok too. Use an interface kernel to pass information if they are physically separate too

node.title: mooseWarnings throw when Moose::_throw_on_error=true
node.bodyText:
Hi,
It might be the intended behaviour, but it is currently the case that mooseWarnings throw when Moose::_throw_on_error=true, even if Moose::_warnings_are_errors = false. It would be nice to have the feature to control whether mooseErrors and mooseWarnings throw independently, either by checking both Moose::_throw_on_error and Moose::_warnings_are_errors inside
mooseWarningStream or alternatively add an additional flag such as Moose::_throw_on_warning.
I wouldn't call this an issue, hence I'm putting this in Discussion, but it'd be simple to implement and for me at least it would be a helpful addition for writing certain unit tests.
Thanks for the info. Seems like an issue to me, adding it to issues.

node.title: Nuclide & Growth Models - MOOSE
node.bodyText: Hello, I'm a new user and I'm currently working on building a nuclide and growth model to simulate the release of recrystallization energy from irradiated PTFE. I was wondering if anyone knew about any papers that discuss building nuclides growth models in the MOOSE framework.
@laagesen - This might be a good question for you to advise on.

Hi @KavyaV28 -
In case you had not seen it, we do a have some documentation pages on the nucleation capabilities in the MOOSE framework:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Nucleation/DiscreteNucleation.html
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Nucleation/LangevinNoise.html
We have done more with the discrete nucleation approach in the past. @amjokisaari implemented a discrete nucleation approach during her Ph.D.
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927025615006564?via%3Dihub
This is not exactly the same as, but most similar to, the DiscreteNucleationForce approach currently available in MOOSE. Additionally this article may be of interest:
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0927025621000963?via%3Dihub

Thanks @laagesen . I hadn't seen that last reference yet (it's from the future!).
Mind if I ask a question about these two papers? Both have an example where nucleation happens throughout the simulation (not just at time 0). In @amjokisaari 's paper, the fitted slope in the Avrami equation is about 2, but in the newer paper, it is about 3. The newer paper says it should be 3 for this case and that it is 2 when nucleation occurs at t=0 and then demonstrates that in an example too. Any idea why there is a discrepancy? Does it have to do with how the timing of the nucleation events is chosen?
@amjokisaari can probably answer that better than me
@laagesen Thank you

node.title: Solution on a mesh possible using Heat Conduction but not NS
node.bodyText:
I have developed a large scale mesh problem that I was able to solve a conduction heat transfer problem on. When I apply the same mesh to a Naiver Stokes problem I am not able to solve the problem on the mesh domain. I am receiving the following error: Current number of dofs per element 72 is greater than AD_MAX_DOFS_PER_ELEM of 50. You can run `configure --with-derivative-size=<n

` to request a larger derivative container.

The numerics associated with the problem are as follows:
Parallelism:
Num Processors:          16
Num Threads:             1
Mesh:
Parallel Type:           replicated
Mesh Dimension:          3
Spatial Dimension:       3
Nodes:
Total:                 5293752
Local:                 325135
Elems:
Total:                 3222656
Local:                 200035
Num Subdomains:          5
Num Partitions:          16
Partitioner:             metis
Nonlinear System:
AD size required:        72
Num DOFs:                37056264
Num Local DOFs:          2275945
Variables:               "velocity" "p" "u"
Finite Element Types:    "LAGRANGE_VEC" "LAGRANGE" "LAGRANGE_VEC"
Approximation Orders:    "FIRST" "FIRST" "FIRST"
Execution Information:
Executioner:             Steady
Solver Mode:             NEWTON
MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP (auto)

As the message suggested, you can run
./configure --with-derivative-size=72

in your MOOSE directory, rebuild MOOSE, and then try to run your problem again. This command reconfigures MOOSE to use a larger container for the AD derivatives used in your calculation.

Does this command work within the terminal command prompt of the moose directory, or is there a file that I will have to modify with this command?
Thank you for your continued attention to my issue.

You would run this command within the Terminal in your moose directory. When it completes, you'll then build and run moose (or your application using that copy of moose) as you usually do. Then you can try your problem again.

Here are the two way I tried to implement what you described, along with the messages that I get.:
(base) [wisetamm@falcon1 moose]$ ./configure --with-derivative-size=72
-bash: ./configure: No such file or directory
(moose) [wisetamm@falcon1 moose]$  ./configure --with-derivative-size=72
-bash: ./configure: No such file or directory
Is it possible that I may need to do a moose update?

This is possible, as your copy of MOOSE would be quite old (older than around September 2020) if the configure file didn't exist in the MOOSE root directory. If you run the git log command in the MOOSE directory, you can see the date of your current version.

One more thing - if you wanted to keep your current version, the configure file should be in the moose/framework directory prior to September 2020. So you could try the configure command I mentioned above there as well.

After running the configure command I am still receiving the max dof error. Here is the output after running the configure routine:
(moose) [wisetamm@falcon1 moose]$ ./configure --with-derivative-size=72
----------- Configuring MOOSE ---------------
configuring with derivative backing array size of 72
configuring with AD indexing type global
configuring with derivative type sparse
checking for pkg-config... /home/wisetamm/miniconda3/envs/moose/bin/pkg-config
configure: checking system for libpng
configuring with libpng support
configure: creating ./config.status
config.status: creating conf_vars.mk
config.status: creating framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h.tmp
config.status: framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h.tmp is unchanged
config.status: executing framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h commands
config.status: creating framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h - prefix MOOSE for framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h.tmp defines
config.status: framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h is unchanged
--------- Done Configuring MOOSE ------------

72 might not be enough. Try 100 for the derivative size.
How many variables do you have in the system?
given velocity depends on u,v, and w, it would appear that there are 5 variables being solved for.

and they're all first order lagrange with what kind of element?
Please let us know if increasing the derivative size worked btw

The nonlinear system information indicates the element type is LAGRANGE_VEC, LAGRANGE, LAGRANGE_VEC. I'll keep updates to my progress for this issue updated on this thread. Thank you for the advise and help.
Performed the moose update and and ran, ."/configure --with-derivative-size=100" in the moose directory. Did a re-make and test of the application. The error is no longer displaying.

node.title: Implementing Linear threshold function (or PiecewiseLinear) as a function of time
node.bodyText:
Hi guys, I wonder how can I implement Linear threshold function as a function of time in moose?
for example in (t,f) coordinate,
I want f = 1 from t = 0 to 1
f = linear line with coordinate of (1,1) to (1.5, 1e-4) from t>1 to t = 1.5
then f = 1e-4 from t>1.5
I know I could do it with type = ParsedFunction with something similar to this
'if(t<5,(-9.81*2700*(1000-z))*(t/5),-9.81*2700*(1000-z))'
also, I know there's PiecewiseLinear function, but I'm not sure how to implement it with t (current simulation time).
is there anything as simple as
 type = PiecewiseLinear
      value = '0 1 1e-4 1e-4'
          t = '0 1 1.5 inf'

?
Thank you.
Kind regards,
Traiwit

Hello
As mentioned in the documentation for the PiecewiseLinear function, the default x-data corresponds to time. So you may define your functions in one of the three ways outlined.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/PiecewiseLinear.html
Best,
Guillaume

got it thanks @GiudGiud
[./density_excav6]
  type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 5 5.5 6 6.5 11'
    y = '2700 2700 1.225 1.225 1500 1500'
[../]
[./density_excav7]
  type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 7 7.5 8 8.5 11'
      y = '2700 2700 1.225 1.225 1500 1500'
[../]
[./density_excav8]
  type = PiecewiseLinear
  x = '0 9 9.5 10 10.5 11'
    y = '2700 2700 1.225 1.225 1500 1500'
[../]

node.title: Outputting sub app results to different directory
node.bodyText:
Hi MOOSE community,
I am running a simulation with several similar sub applications. My MultiApps block references the same input file for each subapp, and uses the positions_file parameter to specify the location of each.
It would be helpful for me if the exodus and csv results from these sub apps were output into a separate directory within the main simulation directory, so that after running my simulation the directory will look like:
-main/
----main.i
----main.e
----main.csv
----subapp/
--------subapp.i
--------main_out_subapp0_out.e
--------main_out_subapp0_out.csv
--------main_out_subapp1_out.e
--------main_out_subapp1_out.csv
--------main_out_subapp2_out.e
--------main_out_subapp2_out.csv
I tired using the file_base parameter in the subapp input file, but this resulted in each subapp output overwriting the last.
Is this possible to do within MOOSE, or is moving the results via the command line after the simulation has finished my best option?
Thanks!
Brent

So if you set the Outputs/file_base in the MultiApp input file, only one output file of a type for multiple subapps will be generated? If this is the case, we possibly need to change the code in MultiApp.C to create different file_base based on subapp ids.

Yes, for example with:
[./csv]
type = CSV
file_base = subapp/out
[../]
in the subapp input, only "out.csv" was created in the subapp folder. Having "out{id}.csv" output instead would be exactly what I'm looking for.
Oh. Sorry about this. Yes, this is something needs to be fixed in MOOSE. I will create an issue.
The issue is here (#17738). I did not try reproducing it but looks like the code is indeed problematic.

node.title: Error with the global AD indexing configuration to run INSFV
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose community,
I am having an issue with the enabling the global AD indexing for the finite volume simulations and I am hoping to get your help on this.
Every time I try to run my input file I get the error I reported below. I ran the "./configure --with-ad-indexing-type=global"  as suggested but this did not solve the issue. The output after running this script is also shown below. I also tried recompiling moose after running this script, but this did not make a difference either.
The input file I am trying to run is one of the example files available in: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/navier_stokes/fv.html
FYI, my Application Version is: snapshot-20-10-27-17866-ge8ca19424f
Thank you in advance
----- Printscreen from the input file -----
*** ERROR ***
INSFV is not supported by local AD indexing. In order to use INSFV, please run the configure script in the root MOOSE directory with the configure option '--with-ad-indexing-type=global'
----- Printscreen of "./configure --with-ad-indexing-type=global" -----
$ ./configure --with-ad-indexing-type=global
----------- Configuring MOOSE ---------------
configuring with derivative backing array size of 50
configuring with AD indexing type global
configuring with derivative type sparse
checking for pkg-config... /usr/bin/pkg-config
configure: checking system for libpng
configuring with libpng support
configure: creating ./config.status
config.status: creating conf_vars.mk
config.status: creating framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h.tmp
config.status: framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h.tmp is unchanged
config.status: executing framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h commands
config.status: creating framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h - prefix MOOSE for framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h.tmp defines
config.status: framework/include/base/MooseConfig.h is unchanged
--------- Done Configuring MOOSE ------------

Hello
You do have to re-build moose after re-configuring it to use global AD indexing.
Did you re-build the navier stokes module / your application including the navier stokes module after running the configure script?
Can you please try again after running make clobberall then re-building it ?
Which object is returning the error? If it doesn't say you may build moose in debug mode with METHOD=dbg make -j xx
Best
Guillaume
